docs.title: PlotSense Hackathon September 2025 🎉
docs.text:
Welcome to the official submissions portal. Browse the teams and projects using the navigation.

👉 Submissions

docs.title: PlotSense Hackathon Judging Guide
docs.text: This document provides the criteria and scoring system for evaluating submissions.

docs.title: 1. Overview
docs.text:
Submissions are divided into two tracks:

  • ML Track: Focus on notebooks, analysis, visualizations, and AI features.
  • Dev Track: Focus on code quality, technical documentation, tests, and contributions to PlotSense modules.

Judges will use GitHub Pages (docs/submissions_index.md) to access each submission.

docs.title: 2. Scoring Criteria
docs.text:
Criterion Weight Description Completeness 25% All required files/folders present (checked automatically by CI). Functionality 25% Notebooks run without errors (ML) or code/tests pass (Dev). Creativity / Innovation 20% Novel approaches, clever visualizations, or algorithmic improvements. Clarity / Documentation 15% Clear README, comments, and explanations of work. Presentation / Video 15% Video demonstrates submission effectively and is easy to follow.

Total score = 100%

docs.title: 3. Review Process
docs.text:
1. Open GitHub Pages submissions index: https://plotsenseai.github.io/PlotSenseAI-Hackathon-September-2025

  2. Navigate to each team’s PR and folder

  3. Verify:
  4. CI status badges: ✅ / ❌
  5. Submission completeness
  6. Test/notebook execution
  7. Video link
  8. Score each criterion (0–5 or 0–10 scale) and multiply by weight
  9. Record scores in judge spreadsheet or Google Form

docs.title: 4. Notes for Judges
docs.text:
• Missing files automatically lower completeness score
  • Minor notebook errors: judge may adjust Functionality score
  • Dev track: ensure tests in tests/ pass
  • Encourage participants’ innovation and creativity

docs.title: 5. Optional Tie-Breakers
docs.text:
• Extra functionality or bonus features beyond the template
  • Clean, reusable code or modular notebook design
  • Innovative visualizations or AI-driven insights

docs.title: 6. Reporting
docs.text:
• Scores are collected centrally
  • Total scores determine winner per track
  • CI reports and submission_report.md artifacts provide objective verification

docs.title: PlotSense Hackathon Contribution Guide
docs.text: Welcome to the PlotSense Hackathon! This guide explains how to set up your environment, make submissions, and ensure your work is correctly reviewed.

docs.title: 1. Hackathon Tracks
docs.text:
• ML Track: Focus on notebooks, data analysis, visualization, and AI enhancements.
  • Dev Track: Focus on improving PlotSense modules, writing tests, and creating technical documentation.

docs.title: 2. Repository Structure
docs.text: plotsense-hackathon/ │ ├─ libs/plotsense/ # PlotSense library (editable install) ├─ submissions/ # Your submissions go here │ ├─ teamname-ml/ │ │ ├─ notebooks/ │ │ ├─ video-link.txt │ │ └─ README.md │ └─ teamname-dev/ │ ├─ src/ │ ├─ tests/ │ ├─ docs/ │ ├─ requirements.txt │ ├─ video-link.txt │ └─ README.md ├─ templates/ # Templates for ML & Dev submissions └─ scripts/ # Helper scripts (index generation)

docs.title: 3. Setup
docs.text:
1. Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/<org>/plotsense-hackathon-2025.git
cd plotsense-hackathon-2025
  1. Create a virtual environment
python -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate  # macOS/Linux
venv\Scripts\activate     # Windows
  1. Install dependencies
pip install -r templates/ml_requirements.txt   # ML track
pip install -r templates/dev_template/requirements.txt  # Dev track
pip install -e ./libs/plotsense
  1. Create a .env file
GITHUB_TOKEN=<your_personal_access_token>

docs.title: 4. Making a Submission
docs.text:
1. Copy the template
# ML track
cp -r templates/ml_notebook_template.ipynb submissions/teamname-ml/notebooks/demo.ipynb

# Dev track
cp -r templates/dev_template submissions/teamname-dev
  1. Add your work
  2. ML: Notebooks, charts, video link in video-link.txt, README.md

  3. Dev: Code in src/, tests in tests/, docs in docs/, video link, README.md

  4. Commit and push your changes

git checkout -b teamname-ml
git add submissions/teamname-ml
git commit -m "Team Sunrise ML submission"
git push origin teamname-ml

  1. Open a Pull Request to the submissions branch with

  2. Submission Checklist

  3. ML Track

    • notebooks/ folder with at least one notebook
    • docs/ folder with at least a pdf
    • video-link.txt
    • requirements.txt
    • README.md

  4. Dev Track

    • src/ folder with at least one Python file
    • tests/ folder with at least one Python file
    • docs/ folder with at least a pdf
    • requirements.txt
    • video-link.txt
    • README.md

CI will automatically validate these. Missing files will cause the PR to fail.

  1. Tips
  2. Regularly push changes to avoid conflicts.
  3. Test notebooks and code locally before PR
  4. Keep commits clean and meaningful
  5. Videos should be concise (max 5 minutes recommended)
  6. Name your team folders consistently (teamname-ml / teamname-dev)

  7. Use the provided template structure to avoid CI errors

  8. Support

  9. For questions or issues during the hackathon:
  10. Open a discussion in the repo
  11. Tag the organizers on GitHub
  12. Check the README.md in the root for additional links and resources
